listWit.witness: London, British Museum Royal 10 A I

editorialDecl.p: Encoding of this text has followed the recommendations of the LombardPress 1.0.0 guidelines for a critical edition.

change.p: File Started for the first time.

div.p: Nunc postquam coaeternitatem Lombardus, I, d. 19, c. 1, n. 1 . This distinction 19 continues the preceding thus because after Lombard determined about the identity of the persons with a real distinction or eternal duration, now he begins to treat about the coequal perfection of the persons.

And he divides it into three because in the first place he shows in what things it consists and with respect to what their equality applies in
general, in the second place he shows specifically those things in which they are equal not from a real difference, in the third place he considers one of predicates specifically. The second begins at
cumque enumeratur ista quasi diversa
Lombardus, I, d. 19, c. 2, n. 1
etc. The third at
quod autem aeternitate Lombardus, I, d. 19, c. 2, n. 5
etc. And this is the division of the present distinction in general
Whether any divine supposite immeasurably perfect is in itself infinitely distinct from any other?

That not because no divine supposite is immeasurably perfect which is clear because, just as one is not the other, so the perfection of one is not the perfection of the other because then there would several immeasurably perfect things, one of which would not be the other.

In the second place, the divine supposites are distinguished from one another by their related properties and by the perfection attributes, therefore they are not distinction from them. The consequence holds because these personal properties are not divine supposites, as is seen.

In the third place, the divine supposites are infinitely distinguished in small ways, therefore. The consequence holds because it does not seem compossible that something is infinitely such in small ways and infinitely such. But the antecedent is clear because the divine supposites are distinguished by a real personal distinction which is the smallest possible distinction.

In opposition, it is argued because the divine supposites are distinguished in such a way that in no mode are they able to be the same suppositionally and not another thing from themselves, therefore. The consequence holds because the degree to which identity is repugnant to distinction, to the same degree do they seem to be distinguished among themselves. The first part of the antecedent is clear because by how much necessity God is God, by the same necessity are the three divine supposites. The second part is clear because, if so, it would follows that in the divine essence there would be a quaternity. The consequent is false.

The first conclusion: any divinal supposite is immeasurably perfect and equal to the other. The proof is because between divine supposites there is the highest essential identity of perfection of many things, therefore. The consequence holds because the highest essential identity of several distinctions is the highest equality of them. The antecedent is proved because a greater essential identity of several things than the identity of the divine supposites is not able to be imagined.

The first corollary: though supposite being is determined under no perfection, nevertheless the uncreated supposite being is of an immeasurabley perfection. The first part is clear because, if so, the Son would not have every perfection of the Father, nor the converse, which is false. The second part is clear through the conclusion.

The second corollary: no created simple thing or composite is able to be as equal to another as the divine supposites. This is clear because no plural created things are as much the same as the divine supposites are the same

Third corollary: though equality or identity of any equal things of the creator it is an infinity less identity than the identity of the divine supposites, nevertheless it is not repugnant according to some denomination that only one is the similitude of similar composites. The first is clear because otherwise the identity of the divine supposits would not be the highest possible identity from nature, which is contra to what has been said. The second part is proved because from the absolute power of God the same whiteness would be able to inform two distinct substances. And consequently this would return similar things and designate white things.

Second conclusion: just as no divine supposite is distinguished from its personal property, so no divine supposite is distinguished from the essential or attributable perfection. The first is proved by taking supposite with the inclusion of the origin, and this is clear through
Jermoe in the Exposition of the catholic faith
Hieronymus, Exposition, xxx
saying
the impiety of the Sabellians who deny the three persons under divinus?? property and place under, for not only the names in this mode but even the names of properties, that is the persons or as they say in Greek the hypostases and subsisting things which acknowledge from these words
Jerome, The Exposition of the Catholic Faith, XXX . The conclusion is clear, and these words are treated below
in distinction 35, in the last chapter XXX . The second part is proved because attributal perfection is the essence itself imported into many things
through a term generally importing a perfection absolutely common to the creator and to the creature according to some analogy from a revealing investigation of creatures into the creature, like wisdom, justice, goodness, and others of this type. But any divine supposite is formally ad really justice, goodness, wisdom, and things of this type, therefore no divine supposite is distinguished from attributal perfection. The first part of the antecedent is clear through the description of the attribute or the attributal perfection, which is able to drawn out from what is said by
Thomas of Strasbourg, in distinction 6 of the first book, in question one, in article one
Thomas de Argentina, I, d. 6, q. 1, a. 1 . Through that which is said generally signifying absolute perfection they differ from notions because, though the generating Father is a kind of perfection absolutely, nevertheless it is not generally because then it would be a perfection in the Son or Holy Spirit. Through that which is said to God and to creature they differ from those things which are not and are not able to be suitable to creatures, like deity, immensity, etc. But through that which is said according to some analogy they differ from those things which we only believe by faith to suit God, and to depend on his free will alone, like to become a man, to be born, to suffer, etc.

First corollary: because the will, intellect, goodness, and attributal perfections of this kind are not and they do not indicate distinct formalities in God. This is clear because otherwise there would be an infinite process in formalities, which is false. The consequence is clear because, if wisdom is formally distinguished from the will, therefore let this distinct formality be a, and it follows that a has another formality, and then it is asked whether this is distinguished from that or that, as before, and thus there will be a proceeding into infinity or there will be admitted that somethings are distinguished formally and they do not have diverse formalities.
Second corollary: every attributable divine perfections within it is formally the same and absolutely equal. This is clear.

Third corollary: though attributes of this type are not pluralized nor distinguished from the nature of things, nevertheless a distinction of reason is had between them or is taken up through the operation of our intellect. The first is clear from what has been said. The second is proved because from the fact that such attributable perfections are not distinguished in God, the plurality of them would not be able to be had unless through distinct conceptions of the same things accepted by creature in whom understanding is one thing, willing is another thing, etc. But such compositions and divisions are operations of our intellect, therefore.

Third conclusion: just as equality among many created things recognizable in the equality of the divine supposites is properly incomparable, so the personal distinction of the same divine supposites is disproportional to every other distinction. The first is clear through what has been said since in no case are several created things as essentially the same as these divine supposites are essentially the same. The second part is proved because this personal distinction in a line of distinctions is not of some quantity, since it is the smallest possible. And in the second place because no distinction recognizable among created things is of the same ratio with this, therefore this is disproportional from one to other.

The first corollary: just as two divine supposites are not greater than one, so one of them is not less distinguished from one that from the remaining two. This is clear because something is distinguished in itself.

Second corollary: though amount any two men there is able to be found properly a personal distinction, nevertheless we do not say properly that this distinction will be greater, lesser, or equal to the divine distinction. This is clear because they are of diverse rationes and infinitely and incompossibly disproportionate because it is impossible that one person is another. Nevertheless it is not distinguished infinitely impossibly infinitely differently
such that the person is distinguished infinitely incompossibly and distantly, and nevertheless is distinguished indivisibly because it is the smallest distinction possible.
The third corollary is the affirmative part of the conclusion when taking supposita with the inclusion of their origin. cum inclusione originis eorum.

Contra primam conclusionem: sequitur quod esset in divinis tria perfecta summe. Consequens falsum quia tantum est unum summe perfectum. Consequentia patet quia quodlibet aequalium ut aequale est alteri est aliquod perfectum sed suppositum divinum non est alteri aequale nisi quatinus est contra illud distinctum aliqualiter ergo quodlibet divinum suppositum ut ab alio distinctum erit summe perfectum et sic erunt tria summe perfectam.
Secundo, sequitur quod erunt infinita in Deo aequalia. Patet quia quaelibet perfectio attributalis erit alteri aequalis.

Tertio, contra secundum corollarium subiectum et accidens eius sunt tantum una quantitate quantum, ergo una quantitate quantum possunt esse aequalia. Patet consequentia quia quantitas est secundum
aequales
quales aequales
vel inaequales esse dicimur secundum Philosophum.

Quarto contra tertium corollarium, sequitur quod maior identitas esset Filii et Patris in divinis quam hominis ad se ipsum. Consequens est falsum quia, sicut verum est dicere Plato est Plato, sic verum foret Patrem esse Filium quod non est dicendum. Sed probatur consequentia quia identitas hominis ad se ipsum videtur esse identitas plurium quia homo est materia et forma suae quae sunt eius partes et sunt plures.

Contra secundam conclusionem, sequeretur quod Pater una relatione et eadem referretur ad Filium et Spiritum Sanctum. Consequens est falsum quia tunc econverso Filius et Spiritus Sanctus una relatione referentur ad Patrem et sic tantum esset una persona. Prima consequentia nota et secunda probatur quia impossibile est quod unum et idem correspondeat duabus relationibus secundum speciem.

Secundo contra primum corollarium, sapientia et iustitia formaliter distinguitur et ex rationibus eorum formativus in creaturis, ergo ubicumque inveniuntur earum formalitates ibi et distinctiones quia infinitas non tollit distinctionem in re.

Tertio contra secundum corollarium, si attributa non esset distincta in Deo sequitur quod potentia iustitia bonitas et huiusmodi essent nomina synomina. Falsitas consequentis patet quia non idem nec eodem modo videntur significare.

Quarto contra tertium corollarium, illa distinguitur quarum unum plurificatur alio non plurificato sed essentia non plurificatur attributa vero sic alias m? intellectus significeret vel deciperetur. Antecedens patet, nam alium conceptum habemus de iustitia, alium de bonitate, alium de clementia.

Contra tertiam conclusionem, divina supposita distinguitur suis proprietatibus, ergo unum suppositum plures habet proprietates quam aliud, ergo in li?a distinctionis certa quantitatis huic distinctioni correspondet, igitur una distinctio adintra est proportionalis vel comparabilis alteri distinctioni.

Secundo, cuilibet proprietati tantum correspondet de ratione d?va quantum ei correspondet de ratione entitativa, sed cuilibet proprietati divinae correspondet propria ratio entitativa, ergo propria ratio di?va, et per consequens quaelibet proprietas addit propriam distinctionem super aliam.

Tertio contra primum corollarium et primam conclusionem, si Pater distinguitur se ipso a Filio, sequitur quod Pater nullo sui convenit cum Filio vel quod Pater non convenit aliquo sui cum Filio. Consequens est falsum quia tunc non esset summe unum et idem essentialiter. Patet consequentia quia illa quae se ipsis distinguitur non convenit aliquo sui.

Quarto contra corollarium, responsivum divinae personae sunt summe simplices, ita quod nec essentia est simplicior personis nec aliqua proprietas cogitabilis in personis est simplicior quam persona, ergo a quocumque talis persona distinguitur se ipsa ab illo distinguitur secluso quocumque alio, ergo seclusa origine distinguitur a se invicem divinae personae. Haec ratio est
Gregorii, distinctione 26, articulo primo, quaestione 2
Gregorius Ariminiensis, I, d. 26, a. 1, q. 2

Ad primum, negatur consequentia, et ad probationem conceditur maior quia, licet
perfectione incomplexa quodlibet divinum suppositum sit immense perfectum, non tamen sequitur quod sint tria supposita perfecta Hugolinus. Aliter potest dici quod consequens est verum quia paciones con?ae conveniunt tribus personis conveniunt per nomina adiectiva vel participia si pure adiective tenentur semper dnr[?] de pluribus scilicet de tribus pluraliter et secundum illam relatam possunt dici tres beati tres aeterni, et sic de similibus
Henricus Gandevensis, parte prima, articulo 49, quaestione 3
Henricus Gandavensis, I, a. 49, q. 3 .
Ad secundum, negatur consequentia et ad probationem dicitur quod inter attributa nullam est distinctio ex natura rei ut patet ex tertio corollario secundae conclusionis.

Ad quartum, primo posset negari antecedens quia quodlibet illorum est quantitas vel propria quantitate quantum. Secundo posset dici quod ratio non est contra corollarium quia quantitas non est de ratione essentiali ipsorum quantorum.

Ad quintum, posset primo dici consequens admittendo et cum ultra infertur, ergo sicut est concedenda ista Plato est plato etc. Negatur haec consequentia secundo et melius potest dici negando consequentiam primam quia identitas hominis ad se ipsum non est proprie identitas plurium sed unius tantum hominis.

Ad primum contra secundam conclusionem, conceditur consequens et ad improbationem quia tunc Filius et Spiritus Sanctus etc. Negatur consequentia quia, sicut Sortes eadem albedine numero potest esse similis Platoni et dissimilis Ciceroni, sic unica relatio duabus relationibus correspondere potest.
Ad secundum, negatur consequentia et ad probationem conceditur quod infinitas divina non tollit distinctionem formalem attributorum simpliciter, sed tollit distinctionem formalem in Deo.

Ad tertium, negatur consequentia, ad probationem dicitur quod, licet illa nomina penitus significent idem in divinis, non tamen significant idem in creaturis, et ideo non dicuntur synomina quia synomina significant idem penitus in quocumque significatum ipsorum reperiatur.

Ad quartum, negatur minor, ad probationem dico quod, sicut essentia non plurificatur, sic nec attributa plurificantur ex natura rei in Deo, licet per diversos terminos exprimamus idem significatum. Et hoc est propter debilitatem nostri intellectus quia aliter capere nec intelligere potest.

Ad primum contra tertiam conclusionem, conceditur maior sed negatur minor quia, si Pater et generans Filius est genitus et Spiritus Sanctus non genitus et sic de singulis. Secundo dicitur quod non sunt plures proprietates incomplexe in uno quam in alio quia quodlibet suppositum est sua proprietas loquendo intransitive. Tertio, dato quod esset plures proprietates complexe, tamen quia consurgunt ex unica et prima ratione d??va, ideo nihil addunt.

Ad secundum, diceret Hugolinus quod non est verum assumptum quia dicit in
ista distinctione quaesitone prima conclusione 4a
Hugolinus de Orvieto
quod quaelibet distinctio in divinis est infinite modica, et tamen est entitas infinite magna. Secundo et aliter potest concedi illud assumptum, scilicet quod tantum correspondet, etc., sed non tantae, et sic non valet illa consequentia, distinctio inter Patrem et Filium est infinita, ergo infinite distinguitur nisi in sensu dato et expresso in corollario ultimo.

Ad tertium, dicitur quod debet intelligi se ipsis distinguitur, id est nulla alia entitate incomplexa. Si tamen consequens intelligitur quod Pater non communiret in essentia cum Filio, negaretur quia utrique est essentia. Item circa illud dicit Hugolinus quod personae divinae se ipsis in gradu distinctionis distinguitur cum quaelibet persona tota sui entitate est essentialiter idem quod alia persona quia sunt summe unum essentialiter. Et dicit ultra quod non convenit aliquo sui quasi aliqua parte sed se totis essentialiter unum sunt.

Ad quartum, dicitur primo quod illa pluralitas non repugnat simplicitati sicut nec multiplicitas personarum simplicitati essentiae. Secundo posset dici quod corollarium non dicit quod absolute per
sonae distinguuntur, sed dicit quod non distinguuntur se ipsis sine inclusione originis, ideo non concludit ratio.

Ad primam rationem in oppositum, negatur consequentia quia una est perfectio trium personarum in plurficabilis. Et ad confirmationem quia perfectum dicitur quasi perfecte factum verum est secundum in positionem nominis, non autem secundum proprietatem significationis.
Ad secundum, patet ex conclusione quod supposita divina sunt suae proprietates et perfectiones attributabiles.
Ad tertium, patet per tertiam conclusionem et corollaria qualiter et quanta sit distinctio divinorum suppositorum.
Nunc postquam Lombardus, I, d. 19, c. 1, n. 1 . Prima conclusio quod secundum fidem catholicam tres personae divinae sunt coaeternae atque coaequales.
Secunda conclusio: quod nulla divinarum personarum aliam praecedit aeternitate aut excedit magnitudine aut superat potestate.
Tertia conclusio: quod licet ista tria, scilicet aeternitas, magnitudo, potestas quasi diversa numerentur in Deo, tamen unum et idem sunt, scilicet divina essentia, simplex, et incommutabilis.

Quarta conclusio: quod Pater non est maior Filio nec Pater et Filius maiores Spiritu Sancto nec maius aliquid duae personae sunt simul quam una necque tres maius aliquid quam duae nec maior est essentia in duabus quam vel tribus quam in una quia tota est in singulis.
Quinta conclusio: quod Filius est in Patre et Pater in Filio et Spiritus Sanctus in utroque et singuli in singulis propter naturae divinae unitatem.

Sexta conclusio: quod nulla divinarum personarum trium est pars divini esse vel divinae essentiae quia singula harum verus et plus Deus est et tota etiam plena essentia divina est, et ideo nulla istarum in trinitate pars est.

Septima conclusio: est quod tres divinae personae dicuntur una essentia non secundum materialem causam ut tres statuae dicuntur unum aurum nec secundum complexionis similitudinem ut tres hominis dicuntur unus naturae vel sexus nec divina essentia praedicatur de divinis personis ut genus de speciebus nec species de individuis nec ut continens de contentis nec ut maius de numeribus.

Octava conclusio: Deus dicitur trinus seu trinitas, non autem dicitur triplex ibi enim non est triplicitas ubi summa est unitas et indifferens aequalitas, in rebus autem corporeis non tantum est una quantum sunt tres simul et plus sunt duae res quam una in Trinitate, vero summa tantum est una persona quantum tres simul et tantum duae quantum una et ipse infinite sunt quia non est finis magnitudinis earum.
